items.title: os object bulk-upload timeout feature

labels.name: SDK
labels.description: Issue pertains to the SDK itself and not specific to any service

items.body:
When uploading files via oci os object bulk-upload we are regularly experiencing failures which cause the oci tool to block and not return, sometimes for days or weeks if left alone.  

It would nice to have a timeout parameter which could cause the oci tool to exit non-zero if the upload processing takes longer than a specified amount of time.

It would also be nice to understand why this happens.  An strace of the process shows it's stuck on a read(0) system call.  lsof shows several open connections stuck in CLOSE_WAIT:

169.254.169.254:http (CLOSE_WAIT)
169.254.169.254:http (CLOSE_WAIT)
129.213.2.151:https (CLOSE_WAIT)
134.70.27.247:https (CLOSE_WAIT)
134.70.27.247:https (CLOSE_WAIT)

This is running on an instance in a VCN within oracle cloud itself, in case that helps

items.title: ImportError: No module named operator

labels.name: SDK
labels.description: Issue pertains to the SDK itself and not specific to any service

items.body:
When running any commands after installing oci I get the following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/oci", line 5, in <module>
    from oci_cli.cli import cli
  File "/opt/oci/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oci_cli/__init__.py", line 8, in <module>
    from inspect import getsourcefile
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/inspect.py", line 41, in <module>
    from operator import attrgetter
ImportError: No module named operator
```
My installation parameters were:
```
Install Dir: /opt/oci
Executable location: /usr/local/bin
Place scripts in: /opt/oci/scripts
```
 
Running oci as root is fine, no errors. But if you're not root, you get that no module named operator error. However, I have given all users access to everything in the /opt/oci directory (R-X)

This installation worked a few weeks ago on other systems I have, but not anymore. 
Version of OCI that doesn't have any problems: ``` 2.10.0```
Version of OCI that has this issue: ``` 2.10.4 ```
Operating system on both systems:
```
CPE OS Name: cpe:/o:redhat:enterprise_linux:7.8:GA:server
Kernel: Linux 3.10.0-1127.8.2.el7.x86_64
```
Python version on both systems: ``` 2.7.5 ```
Python path on both systems (which python): ``` /usr/bin/python ```
OCI path on both systems (which python) ``` /usr/local/bin/oci ```

Please let me know if I can provide any other debugging information.

EDIT:
I have tried completely removing /opt/oci and then reinstalling it with the --oci-cli-version 2.10.0  flag and still get this issue. Maybe this is an issue with an oci-cli dependency?
EDIT 2:
I updated the system to python3 via the directions here:
https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2018/08/13/install-python3-rhel/
Ran ``` scl enable rh-python36 bash ``` then re-ran the oci install via: ``` ./install.sh --install-dir /opt/oci --exec-dir /usr/local/bin --oci-cli-version 2.10.0 --accept-all-defaults ``` and now any user can actually run ``` oci setup config ``` or any other oci command. So seems like a dependency updated behind the scenes and broke RHEL7 python 2.7.X support.

items.title: Raw-requests doesn't correctly handle headers

labels.name: SDK
labels.description: Issue pertains to the SDK itself and not specific to any service

items.body:
When you use `raw-requests` command and try to specify custom headers with hyphens, all the hyphens are dropped:

```
$ oci raw-request --request-headers '{"foo-bar": "baz"}' --http-method GET --target-uri https://objectstorage.uk-london-1.oraclecloud.com/n --debug
send: 'GET /n HTTP/1.1\r\nconnection: keep-alive\r\naccept-encoding: gzip, deflate\r\naccept: */*\r\nuser-agent: Oracle-PythonSDK/2.10.5 (python 2.7.16; x86_64-Darwin) Oracle-PythonCLI/2.9.3\r\nopc-request-id: 08799DD98DB34954A1D3B51EA5807049\r\nfoobar: baz\r\ndate: Tue, 31 Mar 2020 02:35:03 GMT\r\nhost: objectstorage.uk-london-1.oraclecloud.com\r\ncontent-type: application/json\r\nauthorization: Signature algorithm="rsa-sha256",headers="date (request-target) host",k.....
```
Note: `foobar: baz`

It looks to be this line:
https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/blob/master/src/oci_cli/raw_request_cli.py#L59

I believe it needs to call with:
`additional_headers = cli_util.parse_json_parameter('request_headers', request_headers, 'camelize_keys', False)`

else parse_json_parameter is doing a bunch of mangling of the keys.  When I make the change locally, I can see the correct headers:

```
$ oci raw-request --request-headers '{"foo-bar": "baz"}' --http-method GET --target-uri https://objectstorage.uk-london-1.oraclecloud.com/n --debug
send: 'GET /n HTTP/1.1\r\nconnection: keep-alive\r\naccept-encoding: gzip, deflate\r\naccept: */*\r\nuser-agent: Oracle-PythonSDK/2.10.5 (python 2.7.16; x86_64-Darwin) Oracle-PythonCLI/2.9.3\r\nopc-request-id: 87213D716F534058803A044F1D868700\r\nfoo-bar: baz\r\ndate: Tue, 31 Mar 2020 02:38:04 GMT\r\nhost: objectstorage.uk-london-1.oraclecloud.com\r\ncontent-type: application/json\r\nauthorization: Signature algorithm="rsa-sha256",headers="date (request-target) host",k...
```
Note: `foo-bar: baz`

items.title: Requirement for old arrow 0.10.0
items.body:
Is there any particular reason why we force a dependency on `arrow-0.10.0`, which is a release from almost 4 years ago?

Not asking only from a security/support point of view, but also because of convenience.  While it is a best practice to have `oci-cli` installed in a virtual env (in which case versions of dependencies don't make any difference); but when installing as a global module, the hard requirement on an older package version will always lead to upgrade/downgrade clashes.

To be more specific, when doing a global upgrade, `arrow` will get upgraded to the current version (e.g.` 0.15.5`, January 2020); then `oci-cli` will in turn downgrade it to `0.10.0`, November 2016; and so on.

We should remove this hard dependency on `arrow`'s version.

labels.name: SDK
labels.description: Issue pertains to the SDK itself and not specific to any service

items.body:
`install.py` uses `platform.linux_distribution()`, the installation breaks with the following error:

`AttributeError: module 'platform' has no attribute 'linux_distribution'`

Here is the upstream: https://bugs.python.org/issue28167

It was deprecated in 3.5, then recently removed. If anyone knows of a work around in the meantime, it would be much appreciated. Thanks!

items.title: oci image import missing important features

labels.name: Compute
labels.description: Issue pertains to the Compute service

items.body:
This is a request for new feature. The oci-cli still lacks some features that we already have in the OCI web-console for image import. I can mention 2 that are very important:

1 - source-image-type OCI

$ oci --cli-rc-file /dev/null compute image import from-object-uri ... --source-image-type OCI
Usage: oci compute image import from-object-uri [OPTIONS]

Error: Invalid value for "--source-image-type": invalid choice: OCI. (choose from QCOW2, VMDK)

2 - Operating System and Operating System Version (most for Windows licensing feature).

I have some automations that move computes among regions and I'm still excluding Windows OS to avoid non-compliance issues.

Thanks,
RJ

items.title: Wrong json output format for "oci audit event list" with streaming enabled if output is null.
items.body:
I have a code that will loop over all regions and compartments and create the json output for audit events. The problem is that some compartments/regions have nothing to return.

$ oci -v
2.6.6

When I run it without the streaming:
```
$ oci --cli-rc-file /dev/null --profile AEG --region ap-mumbai-1 audit event list --all --start-time 2019-08-30T00:00:00Z --end-time 2019-08-31T00:00:00Z --compartment-id ocid1.compartment.oc1..xxx
$
```

With streaming:
```
$ oci --cli-rc-file /dev/null --profile AEG --region ap-mumbai-1 audit event list --all --stream-output --start-time 2019-08-30T00:00:00Z --end-time 2019-08-31T00:00:00Z --compartment-id ocid1.compartment.oc1..xxx
{ "data":
}
$
```

The json output for streaming is invalid. It should be:
```
{ "data": null
}
```

items.title: install.py create_virtualenv should use venv if it exists

labels.name: SDK
labels.description: Issue pertains to the SDK itself and not specific to any service

items.body:
If an approved Python3 installation already exists, install.py does not need to download and install virtualenv.  It can just use venv, instead.  The following are commands I used to edit v2.5.15 of install.py to replace/modify the contents of the create_virtualenv subroutine to do this:

$ sed -i "/^    download_location = os.path.join(tmp_dir, VIRTUALENV_ARCHIVE)$/,/^            shutil.copy(dll, dest_dir)$/d" install.py
$ sed -i "s/^    cmd = \[sys.executable, 'virtualenv.py', '--python', sys.executable, install_dir\]/    cmd = [sys.executable, '-m', 'venv', install_dir]/" install.py
$ sed -i "s/^    exec_command(cmd, cwd=working_dir)/    exec_command(cmd)/" install.py

items.title: Use correct endpoints for `oci monitoring metric-data post`

labels.name: Monitoring
labels.description: Issue pertains to the Monitoring service

items.body:
When attempting to post a metric - 
```
oci monitoring metric-data post \
--auth instance_principal \
--batch-atomicity "ATOMIC" \
--metric-data "$body" ```
```
I receive an error - 
```
ServiceError:
{
    "code": "NotAuthorizedOrNotFound",
    "message": "Incorrect Telemetry endpoint is being used for posting metrics. Please correct the endpoint and retry the request.",
    "opc-request-id": "6902C490C5CE5D9/57BFA006CB/88E644DF73FD",
    "status": 404
}
```
Per the documentation there is no option to change the endpoint - https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/tools/oci-cli/latest/oci_cli_docs/cmdref/monitoring/metric-data/post.html. Also,
```
$ oci monitoring metric-data post --help
Usage: oci monitoring metric-data post [OPTIONS]

Options:
  --metric-data COMPLEX TYPE 
  --batch-atomicity [ATOMIC|NON_ATOMIC]
  --from-json TEXT
  -?, -h, --help 
```
There is an example (https://github.com/oracle/oci-cli/blob/2ab654c639a50431903dd6b81b0143fb602b0864/scripts/examples/monitoring_metrics_example.sh) that includes an otherwise undocumented `--endpoint` option. 

The endpoints for posting telemetry are documented here - https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/apiref.htm
```
https://telemetry-ingestion.ca-toronto-1.oraclecloud.com
https://telemetry-ingestion.eu-frankfurt-1.oraclecloud.com
https://telemetry-ingestion.uk-london-1.oraclecloud.com
https://telemetry-ingestion.us-ashburn-1.oraclecloud.com
https://telemetry-ingestion.us-phoenix-1.oraclecloud.com
```
The endpoints are documented and predictable, customers should not have to manually specify them.

items.title: Support opc-multipart-md5 checking
items.body:
The CLI should support md5 checksumming for multi-part uploaded objects. By default the CLI uses the multi-part upload feature of the Object Store to improve upload speeds. When the upload is complete the CLI returns the `opc-multipart-md5` value - 
```
...
Split file into 9 parts for upload.
Uploading object  [####################################]  100%
{
  "etag": "167aa4d7-2abc-4341-aaa6-3c176e923ee5",
  "last-modified": "Mon, 08 Apr 2019 21:03:49 GMT",
  "opc-multipart-md5": "JSka2OAb6/CxPOXCOLY4FA==-9"
}
``` 
With the CLI in its current state it's impossible to use the `opc-multipart-md5` checksum to verify that the object was successfully uploaded. The `opc-multipart-md5` is calculated by - 

1. Calculating the md5sum of each part (binary). 
2. Base64 encoding each md5sum independently. 
3. Concatenating the base64 values in order of part #. 
4. Calculate the md5sum of that string. 
5. Append a `-` and the count of parts to that string. 

This checking should be optional and disabled by default. We don't need to ship a complete solution in the first release, we can iterate.  As a MVP the CLI should support an option to output the range of each part and its part number, i.e -  
```
...
{ "etag": "167aa4d7-2abc-4341-aaa6-3c176e923ee5",
  "last-modified": "Mon, 08 Apr 2019 21:03:49 GMT",
  "opc-multipart-md5": "JSka2OAb6/CxPOXCOLY4FA==-9",
  "Parts": {
    "1": [
      "0-50000"],
    "2": [
      "50001-100000"],
    "3": [
      "100001-150000"],
    ...}}
```
This enables the user to manually implement checksumming while minimizing effort to add the feature. Subsequent releases can build on this foundation.

items.title: Honor "Content-Encoding" header for os download operations

labels.name: Object Storage
labels.description: Issue pertains to the Object Storage service

items.body:
The Object Storage Service allows specifying a `Content-Encoding` header so objects can be stored in a compressed format. Web browsers honor content encodings (deflate and gzip), so when viewing a URL for a stored object, the contents are decompressed. The `oci os` subsystem ignores the header and doesn't have an option to configure that behavior, so the objects are always fetched as a compressed binary file.

I think a raw object fetch (the current behavior) is a good default. However, it would be incredibly helpful if there were a flag to also allow decompressing objects as they are fetched. Unfortunately, just doing it via piping to a compression utility isn't practical because at that point the header information is lost. A bucket may have a mixture of both compressed and non-compressed files and the `Content-Encoding` header is the only way to determine which any given object is.

items.title: Fails to install on Windows10 if $env:USERPROFILE has a space
items.body:
If the user's profile directory ($env:USERPROFILE) has a space (i.e. "C:\Users\John Doe") then the installation fails.

Call to **$PythonExecutable** in **install.ps1** will fail with error:

`C:\Users\John Doe\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\python.exe: can't open file 'C:\Users\John': [Errno 2] No such file or directory`

The Python executable file does exist (path is correct) and can be manually run.  Issue is clearly the space in the path name and running from the ps1 file.

Powershell scripts will been to be adjusted to handle spaces in path names.

(Windows 10; Python 3.7.2 64-bit)
